content.intro:
With its incomparable historical heritage, ever-growing number of cars, and 23 million people who aspire to rise socially and improve their quality of life, Beijing offers a striking contrast between its labour class and those who are benefiting from China's rapid growth.

In this historic capital, each neighbourhood in Beijing reflects its millennial heritage. From the fervour within its ancient temples to the charm of the intertwined lanes in the old town, the different districts are following their own path, faithful to what has always been their identity.

As the political capital of the Middle Kingdom, Beijing was home to emperors for centuries. It is the pulse of are fined, erudite country and the iconic headquarters of the powerful Chinese Communist Party. Everywhere in the city, you will perceive the contrast between these two worlds, which coexist astonishingly closely.

It is the artistic capital of a country rediscovering its audacity. You will appreciate the abundance of contemporary creations, one of whose expressions is architecture. The Olympic facilities provided the impetus for dazzling artistic freedom, expressed since then in Pharaonic constructions such as the Beijing Opera house, known as 'the Egg' or the CCTV tower, nicknamed 'Big Pants'.

Beijing is a capital city of paradox, too, in which old men take their birds to the city's lakes and fountains an image of yesteryear and rhinestone-studded luxury cars parade the streets an image of tomorrow.

Capital of nightlife, Beijing never stops completely. You will end your evenings in the exclusive district of Sanlitun, where gilded youth and the expatriate community like to eat out. Everyone goes to its neighbourhood bars, or just a bit further, to Xiu to dance until dawn. There are also popular suburbs like Nanluoguxiang, where young people spend their evenings lulled by music from around the world.

Beijing is also a culinary capital, because, here, you will discover real Chinese food, from street-food stalls to large renowned restaurants. In a country where the pleasures of eating are far from empty promises, dining possibilities in Beijing are endless and satisfy even the most discerning palate.

And, finally, Beijing is the capital of renewal, as the city changes day by day. Within weeks, buildings spring up, city blocks become unrecognisable and lanes disappear in favour of grid-patterned streets.

Between tradition and modernity, Beijing is still finding its way. A city of contrasts in which the past and the present collide, Beijing's future remains to be written: in its political choices, the future growth of the country, and its nascent openness to the world. It is this diversity you will discover during your stay, and it will awaken in you a feeling of China at its deepest and most profound.

content.title: Bottega Fratelli Salvo, genuine Neapolitan pizze in Beijing

introduction.small: Two Neapolitan brothers, Italian products and a unique pizza dough recipe. These are the three ingredients that make Bottega Fratelli Salvo so special, in the heart of the trendy Sanlitun neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bottega Fratelli Salvo, genuine Neapolitan pizze in Beijing

paragraphs.text:
A base that is at once crispy and tender, simple toppings that enhance the taste of the burratina arranged like Chinese dumplings, and a few leaves of basil. The wood oven and handmade pizzas of Bottega Fratelli Salvo transport Beijing locals to Naples in one bite. In the kitchen, two brothers: Daniele and Paulo Salvo, born of a Neapolitan family where making pizzas is a skill passed from generation to generation since 1928. While leaving for Beijing, the two Fratelli retained their grandfather's secret recipe: Salvatore Salvo was indeed a major pizza artist back in Naples. Keepers of this heritage, Daniele and Paulo perpetuate the family destiny, using a bright red wood-fired oven, which you can glimpse at from your table through the open kitchen. Their authentic Neapolitan pizzas are prepared with Italian products, making the Bottega one of the major Italian restaurants of the capital. So much so that a second address opened in the Xinyuanli neighbourhood.

Bottega Fratelli Salvo
2/F Nali Patio 81
Sanlitun Road
Chaoyang District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 6416 1752

www.bottegacn.com

Menu: from 88 CNY

content.title: Jing-A Brewpub, for local beers

introduction.small: The beer bar of a Beijing microbrewery, Jing-A Brewpub seduces with a large selection, including twenty draft beers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jing-A Brewpub, for local beers

paragraphs.text:
Because bars are quite rare in Beijing, Jing-A Brewpub all the more looks like an Eldorado for the hop drink lovers. Amid an industrial setting with exposed brick walls, the place offers no less than 22 different draft beers, as well as seasonal specials, all locally brewed. Jing-A Brewpub is actually the flagship of Jing-A Brewing Co., a local microbrewery created in 2012 and already multi-awarded on an international level. Its speciality? Incorporating typical ingredients in the drink to come up with undeniable Chinese flavours. These include ginger, red yeast rice and Sichuan pepper. You can pair these unique drinks with a few smoked snacks, inspired by Texas barbecues. And if you do not feel like a beer, try the other concepts available at the bar with classic and signature cocktails, also on draft!

Jing-A Brewpub
57 Xing Fu Cun Zhong Lu
Chaoyang Qu
Beijing 100730

+86 (0)60 6416 5195

http://jingabrewing.com/

Drink menu: from 35 CNY

content.title: Moka Bros for healthy fast food

introduction.small: Moka Bros does not only serve coffee. A true hipster hangout, this canteen offers fast, fresh and healthy cooking to eat on the go.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Moka Bros for healthy fast food

paragraphs.text:
Although they are not "blood brothers", Daniel Urdaneta and Alex Molina are two inseparable friends who absolutely love coffee and have therefore come up with the concept of Moka Bros. In their establishment - the third in the Chinese capital - they ride the healthy trend and offer fast food that only uses fresh products. They specialized in "Power Bowls", noodle or rice-based recipes, in which ingredients have been chosen according to their nutritional value and how they can complete each other. It is the case, for instance, of the “protein boost”, a power bowl with quinoa, pumpkin, beetroot and other vegetables topped with parsley and lime. For lunch or a mid-afternoon snack, you may also choose a smoothie, to get your fill of vitamin C. Whichever address you visit, the funky ambiance found in the restaurants of the chain will encourage you to stop and chat with friends while sipping on a homemade juice, or lay back in one of the super mellow beanbag chairs and pick up a book to read.

Moka Bros - Solana Lifestyle Mall
6 Chaoyang Park Rd
Chaoyang District
Beijing

Moka Bros - Sanlitun
Nali Patio D108 South building

81 Sanlitun Beilu

Chaoyang District

Beijing

content.title: Mellower Coffee, for original good coffee

introduction.small: Delicious coffees, with extra design and a twist. Mellower Coffee stretches the boundaries of creativity to deliver a totally unique experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mellower Coffee, for original good coffee

paragraphs.text:
A Shanghai must-go-to, Mellower Coffee has now set up home in Beijing (at last!) to satisfy all coffee lovers. Once inside, the laid back and relaxed atmosphere will take you over, bring you peace, and you won't ever want to leave! This journey continues through the menu, in which originality and creativity blend with the unique flavour of your drink. Their best-seller is definitely the Sweet Little Rain, candy floss hanging over your cup and transforming into a sugary rainfall with condensation. Signature drinks are what makes this place truly something else. For instance, try the hot chocolate with Bailey's or nut liquor, or the Japanese coffee with cherry blossoms for a magical and timeless break. Let your eyes wander in awe over the subtle aesthetics of your order and remember to snap a picture for the memory!

Mellower Coffee

content.title: Yi Pin Xiao Long, Sanlitun's latest safe bet

introduction.small: Located in the heart of Beijing, Yi Pin Xiao Long is the ideal place to discover traditional Chinese cuisine in a friendly and laid-back atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Yi Pin Xiao Long, Sanlitun's latest safe bet

paragraphs.text:
This local canteen offers a perfect opportunity to set off the beaten track and (re)discover Chinese culinary customs. Enjoy the famous xiaolongbao, meat-stuffed ravioli plunged in hot soup, a genuine Pekingese ritual. The different steps of how to eat this meal are even drawn out on the main wall of the restaurant. Noodle lovers will also be pleased by the various sweet and savoury flavours available, by way of spicy dishes. A true delight!
As for the decoration, wooden tables and weaved bamboo ceiling lights add to the warm hues to create a friendly and welcoming ambiance. You can also come as a family, as the restaurants is kid-friendly: just like you, they will love experiencing surprising new flavours.
Make your way to this hidden lair amid modern Chinese skyscrapers. The discovery of this atypical and flavourful culture will undoubtedly satisfy your taste buds and craving for unusual getaways.

Yi Pin Xiao Long
1 / F, Tongli Studios
43 Sanlitun Beijie
Chaoyang District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 6463 8199

Menu: from 12 CNY

content.title: Hulu, gastronomical tapas for absolute pleasure

introduction.small: Tapas from all over the world, brunch, dinner or a simple dessert… In Beijing, Hulu aims at high-quality food with first rate ingredients.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hulu, gastronomical tapas for absolute pleasure

paragraphs.text:
Cold cuts platters, olives and homemade nacho chips, quail eggs with thinly sliced cucumber, pâté and gravlax salmon avocado toasts… Hulu's menu lays its cards on the table, with a wide range of colourful tapas that reveal their sumptuous flavours. Small portions are called for, with enough to snack on here and there. Round the meal off with a mascarpone and mango cake, or the chocolate and basil fondant. The restaurant also serves brunch, with avocado toasts coming together with various egg recipes (scrambled, Florentine, Benedict…). The address favours the use of premium-quality ingredients, yet still manages to offer high-end food at very affordable rates. The warm welcome and casual atmosphere make Hulu an ideal spot for romantic dinner or family brunch on the rooftop.

Hulu
3F Taikoo Li South

Chaoyang District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 6512 5701

http://trb-hulu.com/

content.title: Mojo, a restaurant in gold

introduction.small: Italian cuisine remains a sought-after delicacy in the most modern capital in the world. Mojo offers a delicious gastronomic alternative to its select clientele...

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mojo, a restaurant in gold

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of the Chaoyang district, Italy has taken up residence at Mojo's kitchen. This luxury gastro lounge, inspired by a British concept from the 80s, aiming to offer high quality gastronomy in a welcoming bar setting, delights the finest gourmets eager for new taste experiences.
While the interior of this upscale restaurant is adorned with gold leaf, from the shelves of the cellar to the bar counter, its kitchen is also a real treasure. Inside, three internationally-acclaimed Italian chefs place appetising pizzas in their wood-fired oven, cook pasta al dente and stuff handmade ravioli with foie gras. The sommelier will guide you, according to your taste, in choosing from one of the restaurant's 1,000 wines for the best possible experience. As the sun sets behind the skyline, the atmosphere awakens at nightfall and the music takes on electro overtones to make you dance until dawn…

Mojo
Workers Stadium East Gate Road
Chaoyang District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 0158 3880

www.facebook.com/mojobeijing/

Menu: from 125 CNY

content.title: Wolfgang's Steakhouse, the carnivores' lair

introduction.small: Connoisseurs of very good meat must try this genuine New York institution in Beijing, whether for a business meal or a dinner with friends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wolfgang's Steakhouse, the carnivores' lair

paragraphs.text:
After 30 years as a waiter in New York, meat lover Wolfgang Zwiener founded what would become Park Avenue's best steakhouse. In 2017, the Beijing branch of Wolfgang's Steakhouse was established in the Sanlitun area, just steps away from Sun Park and the financial district, and a stone's throw from the Forbidden City.

In an elegant and convivial atmosphere, meat comes in a wide variety of flavours. Opt for the signature of the house, the unsurpassable T-Bone, dry aged in-house, grilled bacon or a delicious beef tartare. Grilled and marinated items are accompanied by delicious cocktails, served by an expert barman, and wines chosen from among a very wide selection. The less carnivorous will opt for salads or seafood specialties, such as the “jumbo” lobster with marinated shrimp.

Since its opening, the address has been a must!

Wolfgang's Steakhouse
1/F Pacific Centry Place Jia2
Gongti Bei Lu
Beijing

+86 (0)10 6592 4946

www.wolfgangssteakhouse.net

Menu: Porterhouse for two from 1,200 CNY

content.title: Migas Mercado, Spain on the rooftops of Beijing

introduction.small: Barcelona invites itself to the trendy district of Guomao to reveal the best of Catalan gastronomy... A stopover rich in flavour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Migas Mercado, Spain on the rooftops of Beijing

paragraphs.text:
The Beijing culinary scene is indisputably among the most daring in the world. Migas Mercado was born in the heart of the Chinese capital, bringing along a concept inspired by large traditional Spanish dishes.
Located on the seventh floor of a colossal shopping centre, the restaurant is set on a magnificent rooftop, where a sprawling bar takes centre stage. In an elegant and luxurious setting, small lamps appropriately arranged create a sensual and glamourous ambiance.
Curious visitors and locals in search of exoticism come here to taste the best of Iberian cuisine. Delicious cocktails are accompanied by a myriad of tapas and picadillos on the panoramic terrace, offering a breathtaking view. Marinated olives and meatballs mix with crispy croquettes and foie gras burgers. This moment of relaxation is an opportunity to apply the Mediterranean philosophy based on conviviality and easy living.

Migas Mercado
7/F China World Mall
1 Jianguomenwai Dajie
Chaoyang District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 6500 7579

www.facebook.com/MigasBj/

Menu: from 100 CNY

content.title: Bulgari Hotel Beijing, an urban resort in the heart of Beijing

introduction.small: In the bustling city of Beijing, the Bulgari Beijing Hotel is in a natural setting ideally located in the very chic Chaoyang district.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bulgari Hotel Beijing, an urban resort in the heart of Beijing

paragraphs.text:
In the prestigious embassy district, the Bulgari Hotel Beijing is an oasis of luxury and tranquillity for travellers seeking serenity. Nestled in lush gardens that extend down to the river, this urban palace invites nature into the heart of the Chinese capital. Indeed, one only has to stroll through the landscapes designed by the talented Enzo Enea and the spaces of the five-star hotel to notice that culture blends with greenery and design everywhere you look. In the 119 rooms and suites, the contemporary and sober decoration evokes Italian craftsmanship, from the black granite bathtub to the Bulgari bedspreads.

One must stop at the 1,500 sqm spa to indulge in the holistic ritual of their choice, inspired by ancestral Chinese relaxation techniques... for a moment of absolute bliss!

content.title: Lake Shichahai, symbol of Old Beijing

introduction.small: And why not take a boat tour on Lake Shichahai?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lake Shichahai, symbol of Old Beijing

paragraphs.text:
Once a port at the end of the canal linking Beijing and Hangzhou under the Yuan dynasty, Lake Shichahai is now an excellent tourism destination. With an area of 147 hectares, there are actually three lakes: Houbai, Qianhai and Xihai. Located in the heart of the city, those who stroll there will find hutongs, historical residences, cafés, and restaurants...

In summer, you can explore the lake on a small or pedal boat, or even canoe along the shore. In the winter, put on your skates and get out on the ice. Nearby, you will find various activities that will add to your visit of the neighbourhood: the lotus market, a typical street of old Beijing, the house of the poet Guo Moruo, the palace of Prince Gong, the Guo Shoujing Museum, the Bell and Drum Towers, the Guanghua Temple, an important Buddhist sanctuary, or the house of Soong Ching-ling. Today, Shichahai is the trendy part of the capital and a place to relax for the Pekinese in the evening.

Lake Shichahai
Beijing

+86 (0)10 66125717

content.title: Chinese history at the National Museum of China

introduction.small: Discover Chinese history at one of the greatest museums in the world, the National Museum of China.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chinese history at the National Museum of China

paragraphs.text:
The National Museum of China was created in 2003 in the wake of a merger of the Museum of Chinese History and the Museum of the Chinese Revolution. Today you can discover art, culture and history and see the results of research, archaeological discoveries and cultural exchanges all on exhibit. With its 192,000 sqm, you can stroll among some 40 galleries and visit the two main exhibitions - "Ancient China" and "The Road of Rejuvenation" - in addition to a dozen others, notably on world civilization during the modern period and more about traditional arts and cultural relics.

You can spend a day admiring a remarkable collection of about a million historical treasures, including bronze, porcelain, jade, antique gold, silver and coin jewellery. There, where religion and politics mix, you will advance, throughout your visit, under the gaze of portraits of Buddha and Mao.

National Museum of China
16 East Chang'an Avenue
Dongcheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 65116400

http://en.chnmuseum.cn/

content.title: A walk in Beihai Park

introduction.small: Next to the Forbidden City, Beijing offers an oasis of water and greenery.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A walk in Beihai Park

paragraphs.text:
A long, beautiful walk awaits you within the 68 hectares of Beihai Park, with a 39-hectare lake taking pride of place. This imperial garden is more than 1,000 years old, its construction having begun under the Liao dynasty, but the majority of the buildings date from the time of the Qing, from the middle of the 15th century.

Let yourself go in this immense natural setting and travel back in time. On the central islet reigns the emblem of the park: the White Pagoda, a white stupa erected to show the support of the Shunzhi Emperor for Buddhism. As you walk through the park, you can admire the Jing'an Temple, "temple of eternal peace", the Round City, the Nine-Dragon wall, the Five-Dragon Pavilion, the Quieting Heart Room for meditation, the botanical garden and even a tree planted during the Tang dynasty (618-907).

In the summer, rent a boat to sail quietly on the lake and, in winter, imitate the Beijing residents who will be playing on the ice.

Beihai Park
1 Wenjin Street
Xicheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 64040610

www.ebeijing.gov.cn/Travel/Sightseeing/Beihai_Park/#

content.title: The great luxury of the Legendale Hotel Beijing

introduction.small: Imagine yourself as a Chinese emperor by reserving a room in this five-star hotel in the heart of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The great luxury of the Legendale Hotel Beijing

paragraphs.text:
If a luxury hotel is what you are looking for, you have come to the right place. Welcome to the Legendale Hotel in the centre of Beijing, located at the crossroads between the ancient and modern cities.
With its 17 floors, this five-star hotel will impress you right upon your arrival. Each of the 390 rooms and suites offers a retro decor that gives them an undeniable charm. Yellow and blue tones predominate amidst a baroque style, with marble dressing up the bathrooms. The Legendale Hotel offers a choice of seven restaurants and bars to pick from. Opt for Macau, under an immense dome, where you will be served typical Chinese cuisine: steamed chicken in lotus flowers, sautéed shrimp in spicy sauce, pigeon in mushrooms and XO sauce, and a wok of pork with shallots. End your day at the Noble Club on the 16th floor with a cocktail in Beijing's evening lights.

Legendale Hotel
92 Jinbao Street
Dongcheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 85113388

http://legendalehotel.com.cn/

Rooms: from 1,160 CNY

content.title: 798 Art District, stronghold of the contemporary Beijing art scene

introduction.small: Enter a new Beijing, more urban, more contemporary, but a place full of history where artists from all over China come to express themselves.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 798 Art District, stronghold of the contemporary Beijing art scene

paragraphs.text:
In a decommissioned 1950s factory that now shelters the Beijing Academy of Fine Arts, just a few miles away from Tiananmen Square, Wangfujing Street and the Forbidden City, the Gracie Art Hotel attracts many visitors drawn by the appeal of the 798 Art District, this new neighbourhood entirely dedicated to contemporary art, where galleries, cafes, boutiques as well as culture and fashion events are aplenty.
With complimentary champagne and a warm welcome upon your arrival, everything is done to make your stay in Beijing go as smoothly as possible. In a stripped-down decor, you'll make the most of a spacious room with high ceilings, wooden floors and walls adorned with colourful modern artwork. A little detour to the Maison Yi is worth your while, for the hotel restaurant has won "Best Sunday Brunch" in The Beijinger newspaper. Here you can delve into seafood of Asian and Mediterranean influences.

798 Art District
2 Jiuxianqiao Lu, 798 Hao Yuan Yishu Qu
Beijing

+86 (0)10 5978 9114

www.798district.com

Rooms: from 700 CNY

content.title: Inside the “bubble” of the National Centre for the Performing Arts

introduction.small: Designed by architect Paul Andreu, the National Centre for the Performing Arts of Beijing shines with luxury and intrigues by its form. Discovery of an artistic structure.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Inside the “bubble” of the National Centre for the Performing Arts

paragraphs.text:
Have you noticed? You know, this floating island with deliciously worked curves. Also known as the 'Great National Theatre', the National Centre for the Performing Arts invites art lovers under its glass and titanium shell with its 150,000 m², composed of an opera hall, a concert hall and two theatres. Like an island lost in the middle of the Ocean, the cultural complex sails on an artificial lake in which it is gently reflected.

Opened to the public in 2007, the National Centre for the Performing Arts has been ranked by the American magazine Business Week as one of the top ten architectural creations for energy savings and eco-friendly design.

National Centre for the Performing Arts

Xicheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 6655 0000

http://en.chncpa.org/

content.title: Chuan Ban, a spicy-tasting escapade

introduction.small: Awarded the best Sichuan restaurant in Beijing in 2011, the Chuan Ban promises some spicy tastes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chuan Ban, a spicy-tasting escapade

paragraphs.text:
If you are an enthusiast of Sichuan cuisine, known for its very spicy savours, this place is for you! Atypical dishes are offered such as si ji dou, dried and fried spicy green beans, or the dan dan noodles in red pepper oil, Sichuan mustard leaves and minced meat. If your mouth is not yet on fire, try the very popular spicy beef, not to mention the huajiao, the famous steak with pepper.

Gauge the seasoning level on the menu with the number of stars next to the dish. If you have a delicate palate and a fragile stomach, opt for sautéed mushrooms and a mix of vegetables, or the braised pork belly. The restaurant is often full, and reservations are not accepted. We recommend arriving before 6 p.m. or after 8 p.m.

Chuan Ban
5 Gongyuan 1st Alley
ChaoYangMen
Dongcheng Qu
Beijing

+86 (0)10 6512 2277

Menu: around 40 CNY

content.title: An unforgettable stay at the Fairmont Hotel

introduction.small: In the heart of the business district of Beijing, the Fairmont Hotel opens its doors for a five-star stay in an exceptional setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: An unforgettable stay at the Fairmont Hotel

paragraphs.text:
A mix of authenticity and modernity permeates the 222 rooms and suites where you can admire a vast panorama of the city thanks to immense picture windows.
For lunch or dinner, you will have the choice between several exceptional spots. The Cut offers an unforgettable culinary experience overlooking the kitchens, where you can admire the chef masterfully preparing Asian specialities like chrysanthemum soup, chicken in Sichuan pepper, fried lotus roots with spicy sauce or pork Shumai. Elegant and contemporary, Lunar 8 offers Asian specialties such as Peking duck in plum sauce, the famous tandoori chicken, various woks as well as sushi and sashimi. After a visit to the champagne bar or lobby bar where you can sample delicious Asian-inspired pastries at tea time, relax at Willow Stream Spa or the indoor heated pool.

content.title: Biking around Houhai Lake

introduction.small: Beijing offers bicycle rentals which make many people happy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Biking around Houhai Lake

paragraphs.text:
Thirteen million bicycles circulate in Beijing. This is a popular means of transport in the city, which has a flat topography. The shores of the lakes of the city centre, such as Houhai, make for a magnificent ride, which is why bikes are especially popular in this district with its crowds of happy revellers.

You will definitely want to extend your tour in order to discover this very old picturesque neighbourhood. You will need to take the long way round to see the beautiful homes surrounding the lake and historic sites such as the Bell Tower or Tongrendang pharmacy, renowned for its traditional-medicine products.

We recommend you observe the way the Chinese cycle, which is different from ours: for example, they never stay on the bike's seat when they're not pedalling, and they always get off their bicycle when they are about to stop.

Houhai Lake
Shichahai, Xicheng
Beijing

content.title: Hotel Côté Cour Beijing: in the heart of the hutongs

introduction.small: Happiness is staying in a traditional Beijing house from the imperial period.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Côté Cour Beijing: in the heart of the hutongs

paragraphs.text:
Experiencing Chinese hutongs is worth it. A former schoolhouse, the Hotel Côté Cour is a peaceful oasis amidst the narrow streets, lined with small shops and street vendors, in old Beijing. This 600-square-metre courtyard has been elegantly furnished by its owner, Mrs. Cao Kun, who enthusiastically scours the antique stores and flea markets of the city.

As tradition dictates, the rooms are connected to the courtyard and decorated with engravings and photographs. The woodwork in the elegant bathrooms is entirely painted with motifs and traditional Chinese landscapes. Extremely central, this hotel is intimate-only 14 rooms. Upstairs, a glass-roofed restaurant-bar overlooks the terrace. You will enjoy the mild summer and fantastic views in a place full of history and symbolism.

Hotel Côté Cour Beijing
70 Yanyue Hutong
Dogcheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 65239598

www.hotelcotecourbj.com/

Rooms: from 1,002 CNY

content.title: A memorable stay at the Rosewood Beijing

introduction.small: A hotel that offers everything you dream of: luxury, calm, and voluptuousness.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A memorable stay at the Rosewood Beijing

paragraphs.text:
At the Rosewood Beijing, everything is tastefully chosen. A stay here reflects a Chinese art de vivre of sober refinement that is authentic and soothing. This is a place for discoveries, sensations, and surprises that delight the soul, mind, and body of every traveller.

Upon your arrival, you are greeted with flowers and plants offering delicate fragrances. The highly qualified staff takes every effort to make your stay outstanding. The rooms are spacious, and carefully furnished, combining contemporary design with traditional decoration. You feel like you are in a second ‘home', soft and reassuring, which rings with the distant sounds of ancient China.

Although the hotel is new, it is already ranked among the best in Beijing.

Rosewood Beijing

Rooms: from 1,785 CNY

content.title: A timeless journey at Temple Restaurant Beijing

introduction.small: When the talent of the best chefs merges with the perfection of the setting, you have the promise of an unforgettable journey.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A timeless journey at Temple Restaurant Beijing

paragraphs.text:
Located in a 600-year-old temple, this restaurant exerts inevitable charm and magic. Tastefully refurbished, with subtle lighting, it daringly allies tradition and modernity through glass, steel, ancient tile and stone. Its refinement is astounding.

But that is not all. Ignacio Lecleir, formerly at Boulud in Beijing after collaborating with Daniel Boulud in New York, has concocted a French-inspired gourmet menu very much in the tone of the restaurant. You will experience happiness with the various chef's specialities, preceded by delectable appetisers. Enjoy a seabass with kumquats, rigatoni with foie gras, a frozen pistachio and jasmine tea, or the chocolate fondant with passion fruit. A sommelier will help you choose from the expansive wine list. And after the meal, you can end this exceptional evening with a walk inside the temple.

Temple Restaurant Beijing TRB
Shatan N Street
Dongcheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 8400 2232

www.facebook.com/trbcn/

Menu: around 500 CNY

content.title: Dali Courtyard: charming traditional houses

introduction.small: Located near Nanluoguxiang and Ghost Street, a restaurant hidden inside a hutong.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dali Courtyard: charming traditional houses

paragraphs.text:
Dali offers a unique menu featuring specialities from Yunnan, a south-western province of China. About 15 dishes are brought to your table, like steamed spicy fish, crispy chicken and grilled tofu – if well cooked, the latter is a pure delight.

Everything is seasoned with the flavours of this region that borders Vietnam, Laos, and Burma that is to say, chillies and lemongrass. The garden, central to the restaurant, overlooks several rooms whose small size emphasizes the restaurant's confidential atmosphere. The music is soft and the sound of the fountain lulling.

In summer, the light breeze that blows in the garden makes Dali one of the most enjoyable places to be. For dinner under the majestic trees or glass roof, book ahead, as the restaurant is very popular.

Dali Courtyard
67 Xiaojingchang Hutong
Beijing

content.title: The Ming Tombs: land of eternity of the imperial family

introduction.small: 45 kilometres north-west of Beijing, the Ming Tombs are home to the eternal rest of illustrious figures of the dynasty.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Ming Tombs: land of eternity of the imperial family

paragraphs.text:
In power between the 14th and 17th centuries, the Ming period marks an extremely radiant chapter in the history of the country. Their reign coincided with a cultural renaissance in the arts and in literary production. During the Ming dynasty, China shone brightly. The tour takes you to the cemetery where the imperial tombs are. In China, ancestral worship is an integral part of tradition. These illustrious remains are housed in small imperial palaces, the colours of the sky (yellow tiles) and earth (red walls).

Everything has been kept in good condition to protect the cultural heritage contained within. The “sacred path” or “way of the spirits” is also worth visiting: nearly seven-kilometres long, it leads you from the entrance of the cemetery to the Ming Tombs. Along the way are sculptures of mythical animals and dignitaries of the court. The walk will transport you to a time populated by Chinese unicorns, dragons, and phoenixes.

Ming Tombs
Changchi Rd
Changping
Beijing

+86 (0)10 60761422

content.title: Xiu: a Beijing nightlife hot spot

introduction.small: Finish the evening with music, dancing and tasty cocktails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Xiu: a Beijing nightlife hot spot

paragraphs.text:
Xiu welcomes you to the sixth floor of the Beijing Yintai Centre, in a resolutely chic club to finish your fashionable and festive evenings. The atmosphere inside is ensured by a large fireplace containing roasting ducks. The central bar stands out for its size and contemporary design, but there are also four other themed bars: here, a wine cellar; there, a cigar bar…

Several salons with original themes revolve around a main hall for dancing and listening to the international music groups that come regularly to this fashionable place. Most notable, however, is the majestic roof terrace, which offers Beijingers a very nice option for balmy summer evenings. Have a drink in one of the small decorative houses.

“Xiu” means “elegant” in Chinese, which suits this upscale bar perfectly.

Xiu
2 Jianguomen Outer Street
Chaoyang District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 8567 1108

Menu: around 70 CNY for signature cocktails

content.title: Panjiayuan Market: a flea market on a Chinese scale

introduction.small: Because bargain hunting in China is a national sport, you will unearth treasures in this market, which sells local crafts.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Panjiayuan Market: a flea market on a Chinese scale

paragraphs.text:
Penjiayuan, commonly called the ‘thieves' market', is full of stalls and swarms of onlookers, as well as second-hand dealers.

Here you will find remnants of the Maoist era, more souvenirs now than objects of veneration. This is also an opportunity to discover local crafts, including paper cutting, an ancient Chinese art that still adorns the windows of houses in the New Year to ward off evil spirits…

In the joyful chaos in the aisles, you can find a plethora of traditional items: hat boxes with pieces of porcelain, calligraphy brushes with little trinkets. Here, as elsewhere, everyone bargains. If you don't play the game, it will only frustrate the seller and the buyer! But don't delude yourself: real Chinese antiques are found more frequently at Sotheby's!

Panjiayuan Flea Market
18 Huawei Li
Panjiayuan Road
Chaoyang District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 6774 1869

content.title: The New World Beijing Hotel: where the future meets the past

introduction.small: A five-star hotel dedicated to the wellness of an international clientele.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The New World Beijing Hotel: where the future meets the past

paragraphs.text:
Located in the heart of the capital, near Wangfujing and major tourist sites such as the Forbidden City and the Temple of Heaven, the New World Beijing offers several types of rooms, all furnished in a resolutely contemporary, sophisticated design style with subtle Eastern touches.

This hotel has 309 rooms and the largest suites in the city. The presidential suite occupies no less than 400 sqm, with a kitchen and dining room that accommodates up to eight people or a large family. The hotel's spa is a haven of peace that will offer you a moment of rest for the body and mind.

The New World Beijing is really the ideal place to make the most of your stay in the Chinese metropolis.

New World Beijing Hotel

content.title: Opposite House: modern beauty

introduction.small: A gem sequestered behind tinted windows in the heart of trendy Sanlitun.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Opposite House: modern beauty

paragraphs.text:
The exterior of Opposite House is already a surprise. Like a coloured block in acid shades of green, it resembles a Lego brick and intrigues passers-by as it detonates the landscape. Designed by the famous Japanese architect Kengo Kuma, author of many architectural innovations, it is the place where stars, wishing to stay in the fashionable district, stopover in Beijing.

The hotel lobby, a true art gallery, houses various works. Hotel guests circulate freely in this audaciously furnished space, where aesthetic concerns are the priority. The 99 rooms meet every criteria of luxury. They are elegant and comfortable, in a contemporary Zen style, and enhanced by lighting that plays with the subdued natural light coming through the huge glass facade.

Here, the discreet, efficient service, which is always attentive to your comfort, makes you feel like a host, not a guest. And, make sure you enjoy the hotel pool, which could not be more amazing.

Opposite House
Taikoo Li Sanlitun North

Beijing

+86 (0)10 64176688

content.title: Views from the Great Wall

introduction.small: Walk in the footsteps of history, back to a mythical China.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Views from the Great Wall

paragraphs.text:
Ranked among the seven wonders of the world, the Great Wall deserves its title. Built over 2,000 years of history to defend China from barbarian invasions, it passes through mountains, deserts, and grasslands. You find yourself imagining men stationed in the fire towers, aiming their weapons through the slots in the wall to stop barbarian intrusions.

This is a must-see. It is fascinating to walk on the fortress, which stretches out infinitely in either direction. An original way to explore the Great Wall is on horseback at the foot of the ramparts in the Kangxi Grassland. Rent horses 10 km from Badalin for a 1 ½-hour ride. Even beginners can do this. Then, go enjoy the fabulous view from the wall.

Great Wall

+86 (0)10 6716 0201

www.tour-beijing.com/horseback_riding/badaling_great_wall.php

content.title: Black Sesame Kitchen and its host table

introduction.small: Making new friends and the pleasure of eating.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Black Sesame Kitchen and its host table

paragraphs.text:
The Black Sesame has a very original concept: here, you dine together at one big table, where your illustrious dining companions become friends for an evening. Everything is cooked on the spot: with just a snap of your fingers the expert cooks busy themselves behind their stoves, cooking up a variety of the best Chinese dishes. Once prepared, the dishes are divided between all the guests at the table.

Without question, this restaurant will leave a lasting memory and give insight into Beijing's warmth and friendliness. Hidden in the heart of the hutongs, this restaurant is a rising star in the gastronomic landscape of the city. For the most curious, the address also provides cooking classes.

Black Sesame Kitchen

content.title: The Forbidden City: a palace of myriad fantasies

introduction.small: A feeling of eternity engulfs you as you discover the magnificence of the Imperial Palace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Forbidden City: a palace of myriad fantasies

paragraphs.text:
This residence of ancient rulers, immortalised in the film The Last Emperor by Bernardo Bertolucci (1987), incites admiration and recalls the grandeur of Old China. The highest seat of power, betrayal, and conspiracies, the “Purple Forbidden City” is to the Chinese what Versailles is to the French: a quaint and touching relic of a bygone era that continues to pervade the soul of the country.

Under the snow are buildings of unsurpassed grandeur that invite meditation. Though much of the furniture is now in the Taipei National Palace Museum in Taiwan Chiang Kai-shek took it there when Mao came into power the magic of the place is contained in its complex architecture, which permeates all the ancient monuments of the city. Yellow, the imperial colour, dominates, together with red for prosperity. The emperor, who bore the title of “Son of Heaven” made this principal residence the jewel in the crown, the symbol of his power and the eternal legacy of Chinese architectural art.

Forbidden City
4 Jing Shan Qian Jie
Dongcheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 8500 7421

https://en.dpm.org.cn/

content.title: Wandering in Wangfujing

introduction.small: Go window-shopping on this street, halfway between the old traditions and modern China.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wandering in Wangfujing

paragraphs.text:
Twinned with the Champs-Élysées in Paris since 2002, Wangfujing street is near the Forbidden City. It offers a vision of contemporary China that contrasts with that of the historical centre. Indeed, Wangfujing is packed with cosmopolitan businesses, including the best-stocked foreign bookstore in Beijing. There is also a branch of Neiliansheng, manufacturer of the famous embroidered slippers worn by Chinese writer Lao Shi. These handmade slippers reflect ancestral know-how.

This large avenue is a tourist destination for those from the provinces. Watch locals rub shoulders with those from the countryside, who wander around amazed at the opulence and splendour of the shop windows. At the end of the street is a Catholic church where ceremonies are regularly held, a rare example of a religion service, which the authorities tolerate with difficulty.

content.title: Ghost Street: varied working-class cuisine

introduction.small: Gourmet night owls: welcome to this famous haunt of local cuisine!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ghost Street: varied working-class cuisine

paragraphs.text:
“Ghost Street” is so called because the Chinese pronunciation of the street's real name, Guijie, is close to the word “ghost”. There are a hundred restaurants throughout Dongzhimen Dajie. It is a great place to discover culinary traditions like Chinese fondue, pork with sweet and sour sauce, or Sichuan pepper crayfish. Red lanterns illuminate the scene and signal to passers-by the many eateries.

They are open day and night, which is important in a country where it is difficult to get a table in a restaurant after nine at night. Frequented by many Beijingers, picturesque and always lively, Ghost Street offers an incongruous spectacle and is known for the succulent flavours of Asian cuisine and its uninterrupted nightlife.

Be aware that the place is more popular when spring comes, as you can enjoy many terraces on the sidewalk.

Guijie
Dongcheng District
Beijing

Menu: around 50 CNY

content.title: Source: the pause that refreshes

introduction.small: Sichuan is honoured in this charming restaurant, located inside a former warrior's home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Source: the pause that refreshes

paragraphs.text:
There are some real gems in the hutongs, and the Source is one of them. Camouflaged in the heart of the crooked streets of Nanluoguxiang area, it is a beautiful setting in the home of an ancient Chinese general who had made it his Beijing residence. The Source, whose address remains relatively confidential, offers Sichuan cuisine, whose spicy specialities are sure to seduce you: the menu allows you to discover a festival of flavours characteristic of this western corner of China.

This restaurant is extremely charming, with timeless evenings spent on the garden patio or in one of the small private rooms. The carefully subdued lighting and soft music make this a restaurant you will want to return to over and over again.

Source
14 Banchang Hutong

content.title: Watch the stars at the China World Summit Wing

introduction.small: Under an open sky, discover a magnificent panoramic view of the city of Beijing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Watch the stars at the China World Summit Wing

paragraphs.text:
The hotel sits atop a tower of glass and steel, a marvel of technology and modernism. You will be propelled 330 metres up to the 64th floor, where the higher rooms are located. From each of them, you can admire the roofs of the city and the mountains that surround it.

This view is one of the best features of the property, with its infinity pool high up, which makes you feel like you are floating in the air. Telescopes are available to make the most of the view. The rooms are furnished in classic style, enhanced with Chinese touches. Bathed in subdued lighting, they are among the most comfortable in the city.

Finally, the hotel lobby is decorated with an amazing work of art combining mountains and foliage, a sort of Asian reverie in the purest tradition of Chinese art. Dinner at Grill 79 and a drink at the Atmosphere bar are also special moments that should not be missed.

China World Summit Wing
Jianguomen Outer St
Chaoyang District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 65052299

www.shangri-la.com/beijing/chinaworldsummitwing/

Rooms: from 1,883 CNY

content.title: Temple of Heaven: a bridge between earth and sky

introduction.small: A UNESCO World Heritage Site and symbol of Chinese ancestral beliefs.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Temple of Heaven: a bridge between earth and sky

paragraphs.text:
Off the main streets leading to the south of the city is the Temple of Heaven, the emblem of Chinese heritage. Built in the 15th-century, the building underwent a ten-year renovation as part of efforts by the government to host the Olympic Games of 2008.

The Chinese are, by nature, morning people. Go to ‘Tiantian' at dawn to see their dance and gymnastics rituals. Authenticity wins! It is also a way for Beijingers to avoid the scourge of pollution, which escalates at sunrise when the workday starts. The temple is a UNESCO World Heritage Site whose symmetrical complement is the Temple of Earth in the north of the city. The Temple of Heaven established the legitimacy of emperors and was the place where ritual ceremonies for good harvests were held.

Temple of Heaven
1 Tian Tan Dong Lu
Dongcheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 6702 8866

content.title: An imperial stay at the Aman Summer Palace

introduction.small: An exceptional stay in a mythical setting gives you the illusion of being the emperor of China.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: An imperial stay at the Aman Summer Palace

paragraphs.text:
The Aman hotel, located right next to the Summer Palace, is made up of a series of sumptuous traditional courtyards. As a guest, you can have a private visit to the palace after the gates are closed to the public. The flawless, magnificent decor of the Aman is one of serenity and true luxury in an imperial atmosphere. It is a timeless invitation to travel back to the Ming period.

In the highly refined spa, lighting is hidden behind perforated wooden panels while the pool invites guests to relax and rest.

Finally, no fewer than three restaurants welcome visitors to a gastronomic discovery of unsurpassable standards.

Aman at Summer Palace
1 Gongmenqian Street

content.title: Night market on Wangfujing Street

introduction.small: This market offers a picturesque spectacle, with original culinary experiences for Westerners in search of adventure.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Night market on Wangfujing Street

paragraphs.text:
Wangfujing Night Market offers an incomparable selection of culinary delights of the Middle Kingdom. Some, however, are reserved for the daring: scorpion skewers, lamb tripe, and grilled centipedes are local delicacies that provoke you with their aromas, flavours, and appearance. But there is also, happily, a wide choice of more traditional dishes, such as marinated meat kebabs and steamed dumplings called jiaozi to feast on.

Be careful about spices because the Chinese love eating spicy food and they enjoy watching tourists turn bright red when they encounter a few cleverly chopped and concealed scarlet chillies. The street life is fascinating. And you will realize that it is not a myth: the Chinese really are fond of chicken feet and sea cucumbers.

Wangfujing Market
Wangfujing Street
Dongcheng District
Beijing

content.title: Lama Temple: a Buddhist haven

introduction.small: A princely residence, Buddhist temple and spiritual haven for common mortals.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lama Temple: a Buddhist haven

paragraphs.text:
The imperial colour of the roofs of the buildings of Yonghe Temple, better known as 'Lama Temple', reminds us that it belonged to the emperor before he gave it Tibetan Buddhist dignitaries this, at a time when political power was not so far from spiritual power.

Many Chinese visit this place; you see them in an attitude of prayer and meditation. Stroll through the courtyard and into the buildings, and through the splendid avenue lined with ginkgo trees; light incense sticks and make an offering. Slightly off the path, you will discover a gilded wooden Buddha that welcomes the faithful, then a four-sided Buddha from Thailand.

The surrounding streets also make a very pleasant walk: Yonghegong, with its bars, boutiques, and delicious snacks like baozi (stuffed buns) and Guozidian, chock-a-block with good addresses.

Lama Temple
12 Yonghegong Street
Dongcheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 84191919

content.title: The Summer Palace: imperial resort

introduction.small: A royal visit to the favourite palace of Empress Cixi and symbol of Qing extravagance.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Summer Palace: imperial resort

paragraphs.text:
Visiting the Summer Palace is an exotic walk in imperial China through a majestic park away from the bustle of the city. One can easily imagine the Empress Cixi strolling in the garden, followed by her court, plotting to retain power.

The palace was partly looted and destroyed in 1860, and the Chinese miss no opportunity in reminding foreign visitors of the mischief committed by the Franco-British armies. This happened again during the Boxer Rebellion in the early 20th century. But Cixi invested huge funds in the reconstruction of the imperial domain. The palace consists of pavilions and shaded galleries deployed around the huge Lake Kunming, where you can go boating if the season is right. Go see the famous marble boat, a symbol of the Qing dynasty, which believed it would be eternal. Thirty-six metres long with a stone hull, it outlasted the Qing. It continues to endure, unchanging and eternal, to the delight of all visitors.

Summer Palace
19 Xin Jian Gong Men Lu
Haidian District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 6288 1144

www.summerpalace-china.com/English/index.htm

content.title: Navigate the canals of Imperial Beijing

introduction.small: Despite appearances, Beijing was built around the major water points, vestiges of a bygone era.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Navigate the canals of Imperial Beijing

paragraphs.text:
In the west side of the city, take a walk on the rivers that once connected the Summer Palace to the various lakes. Not all of them are still operational, but it is still possible to travel on the water starting from the northern gate of the Purple Bamboo Park, the starting point of many boats going to the Summer Palace.

The journey takes approximately 30 minutes and will offer you the rare pleasure of being out on the water amidst weeping willows: a significant moment of tranquillity in this busy city. After crossing the majestic Jade Belt bridge with its unique architecture, you will land on the shores of Kunming Lake, near the palace.

Why not finish this maritime excursion on an electric or paddle-boat and see the Shifang, the enigmatic marble vessel for which Empress Cixi emptied the coffers of the kingdom ?

Purple Bamboo Park (Zizhuyuan Lu Park)
Haidian District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 8841 2800

http://zizhuyuangongyuan.com/index_en.aspx

content.title: Learn about Chinese cuisine by making jiaozi

introduction.small: Far from the clichés dishes served by Chinese restaurants in the West, the Chinese culinary tradition is revealed to be rich and varied.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Learn about Chinese cuisine by making jiaozi

paragraphs.text:
Contrary to popular belief, rice is far from being the favourite food of Beijingers. Instead, it is jiaozi, which they have favoured for centuries. Composed of dough stuffed with a mixture of minced meat and vegetables, and heightened with spices, jiaozi represents their cultural heritage, and making them is a delicate exercise.

Take a cooking class and admire the dexterity Beijingers have developed in making this dumpling, which is, at New Year's, what the bûche is to the French at Christmas time.

Since childhood, women have practised the art of jiaozi, chatting while preparing a meal together. The Chinese share a passion for food. Sitting down to eat at home remains both a ritual and a moment of intense pleasure.

Hutong Cuisine
1 Jiudaowan Zhongxiang
Beixinqiao
Dongcheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)159 0104 6127

www.thehutong.com/beijing-cooking-school/

content.title: Explore the city in an original way, on water

introduction.small: In Shichahai, a bucolic ride combines sport and conviviality.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore the city in an original way, on water

paragraphs.text:
In every season, the bravest Chinese swim in the three artificial lakes clustered together in the city centre (Houhai, Qianhai, and Beihai). They believe that cold water invigorates the body and mind! Fishermen wait patiently for a miracle catch, and impromptu go and mahjong games are set up. Ice cycling is the national winter sport for all generations; at the opening of the season, after the first good frost, Chinese families and friends venture on bikes mounted on skis, chairs or ice skates, laughing heartily.

Try this quirky sport; it will give you a good excuse to nibble on Chinese snacks, like candied apples. You will have the feeling of having had fun the way locals do: a fine example of integration, which justifies taking risks!

Qianhai Lake
Shichahai
Xicheng
Beijing

content.title: Jingshan Park, a bird's-eye view over the Forbidden City

introduction.small: On Coal Hill, ribbons flutter in the wind amongst nonchalant walkers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jingshan Park, a bird's-eye view over the Forbidden City

paragraphs.text:
Follower's of exercises that maintain both body and mind, the Chinese handle hoops or brightly coloured ribbons with incredible dexterity. You will be amazed by the spectacle that awaits you in the middle of Jingshan Park, performed to a soundtrack of lively music by all generations of Beijingers. They practice these activities almost daily to stay fit, but especially to pass down ancestral traditions.

The view from the heights of the park is breath-taking. Small winding roads that go past greenery will lead you to the beautiful pagodas at the top of the hill. From this viewpoint, you will never tire of contemplating the roofs of the Forbidden City and those of the old city. This is a walk that all Beijing inhabitants adore.

Jingshan Park
44 Jinshan Qian Jie
Xicheng District
Beijing

content.title: Tiananmen Square: greatness, excess, and Chinese history

introduction.small: Multiple symbols and opposites coexist in this square, the legacy of important moments in the history of the Middle Kingdom.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tiananmen Square: greatness, excess, and Chinese history

paragraphs.text:
Every day at sunrise, the raising of the flag on the square perpetuates the symbol of Republican China. This has been so since the proclamation of the People's Republic of China on October 1, 1949.

Many Chinese tourists come from elsewhere to attend this moving ritual, which takes place before the entrance to the Forbidden City. Tiananmen is said to be one of the largest squares in the world. The mausoleum of Mao, steeped in history, dominates the square. The body of the Great Helmsman is displayed there. You may visit but you cannot stop and look closely.

His embalming has been the subject of much speculation among the Chinese and Chinese historians: done quickly in the midst of political crisis, the body, it seems, has not valiantly resisted the onslaught of time.

Tiananmen Square
Chang'an Jie
Dongcheng District
Beijing

content.title: Dadong: a panel of discovery

introduction.small: For the incomparable pleasure of eating traditional roast duck.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dadong: a panel of discovery

paragraphs.text:
Dadong offers a wide range of Chinese cuisine. Besides duck, whose fame has spread beyond China, you will discover many traditional specialities around large round tables with a lazy Susan in the middle to rotate dishes.

Delicious dim sum, onion shrimp, tofu, lobster and pepper rice… You should know that in China it is traditional to order several dishes and that the guests like to taste a bit of everything. The chefs, wearing their white hats, are either busy in the kitchen or circulating through the restaurant, checking that everything is as it should be. The ducks are roasted over a constant fire.

The preparation of this dish remains a singular spectacle, which it is absolutely necessary to see (and taste!) at least once: waiters get to show off their dexterity when they cut the fillets.

Dadong Roast Duck
1-2 Nanxincang International Plaza
22A Dongsishitiao
Dongcheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 5169 032

Menu: from 100 CNY

content.title: Duck de Chine: the real flavour of roasted duck

introduction.small: In the Hidden City, because of the wall that ensures the discretion of the premises.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Duck de Chine: the real flavour of roasted duck

paragraphs.text:
Hidden in the heart of Sanlitun, the 1949 Club is a group of restaurants that provide discreet privacy for their guests. Duck de Chine is one of their finest establishments. Enjoy, upon arrival, the original architecture of the restaurant.

Start your evening with a stroll through the art gallery next to the restaurant, which displays works of contemporary Chinese artists. The menu at Duck de Chine is a journey through Chinese cuisine, enhanced with a touch of French. The Peking duck is the dish of honour - Duck de Chine's may be the best in all Beijing. The pumpkin with plums and braised oyster mushrooms are especially popular.

One of its secrets lies in the cooking, done over a fire to make the skin crisp and amber, as well as the spice mix, a secret jealously guarded by the cooks. It is eaten in very thin slices with a thin pancake, accompanied by green onion and plum sauce. It is imperative that you order this dish when booking, as it requires special preparation.

Duck de Chine
1949 The Hidden City

Chaoyang District
Beijing

content.title: The Silk Market, a must-go-to

introduction.small: No-holds-barred shopping in the temple of counterfeits.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Silk Market, a must-go-to

paragraphs.text:
The merchants who were once concentrated on ‘Silk Street' are now grouped together in a huge building. Traditionally, the basement is dedicated to leather goods and shoes. On the ground and upper floors is an eclectic assortment of clothing, from vulgar counterfeits to creations by the best local designers. Check out the talented Chinese tailors, whose reputations are well established. Finally, the top floor offers a variety of dime-store merchandise: jewellery, freshwater pearls, and traditional items like mahjong sets and customised seals that are made on the spot. Bargaining is de rigueur. Items in small shops have no ticket price, and, depending on the time or mood, the seller will give you a price that is different from one stall to the next. Make sure the price is right!

Silk Market

+86 (0)10 5676 7766

content.title: Dashanzi: an introduction to Chinese contemporary art

introduction.small: Beijing today is the artistic capital of the country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dashanzi: an introduction to Chinese contemporary art

paragraphs.text:
The Dashanzi district was the first to attract artists. Soon after, galleries and souvenir shops joined together to offer visitors a diverse tour that takes you from a photo gallery to a sculpture exhibition or a museum shop, the last of which being a veritable bazaar of useless objects as entertaining as they are inventive. By showcasing creativity, this area reflects the extremely rapid evolution of the city—it was not that long ago that abandoned factories were here instead of galleries.

There are a few French people who are evolving in this artistic milieu, notably Hadrien de Montferrand and his gallery, and the Chinese-born artist Li Chevalier, who now lives in France. Artists everywhere are the same: their originality clashes, disturbs, and fascinates. Those exhibited in Dashanzi are no exception to the rule: let yourself be carried away by a different art than ours, which is often inspired by China's recent history.

Dashanzi district
4 Jiu Xian Qiao Lu
Beijing

+86 10 6437 6248

www.798district.com

content.title: Waldorf Astoria Beijing: two hotels for the price of one

introduction.small: An unforgettable experience in a hotel perched between modernity and tradition.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Waldorf Astoria Beijing: two hotels for the price of one

paragraphs.text:
This international luxury hotel offers spacious rooms of irreproachable comfort and beauty. Its quality service ensures calm and relaxation for every guest. The Waldorf Astoria Beijing is conveniently located near the city's historic core, so you can enjoy walking in the neighbourhood of hutongs.

Moreover, the hotel offers you, if you wish a walking tour of Shijia Hutong to experience the daily lives of Beijingers. A little farther away, in the Waldorf Astoria Villa Hutong, charming rooms welcome guests looking for a little more privacy, but who are eager to experience a stay in a courtyard. The spa offers high-quality service, combining traditional Chinese treatments with European standards.

A moment of relaxation you will not soon forget.

Waldorf Astoria Beijing
5-15 Jinyu Hutong
Dongcheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 8520 8989

www.waldorfastoria3.hilton.com/en/hotels/china/waldorf-astoria-beijing-BJSWAWA/index.html

Rooms: from 1,768 CNY

content.title: The charm – and discomfort – of hutongs

introduction.small: Discover an authentic, unchanged Beijing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The charm – and discomfort – of hutongs

paragraphs.text:
When you walk in the old city of Beijing, it is to discover the city's real people. Laughing and chattering gaily, Beijingers have a happy, carefree nature. We must not forget that traditional Chinese dwelling slack comfort; the courtyard is generally composed of several wings organized around a common garden, through which one passes to go from one place to another.

For this reason, people are accustomed to chatting with their neighbours, eating a little something, washing clothes, or simply watching the spectacle of the city out in the open. The old man on the street corner will stare at you without embarrassment, ready to engage in conversation or challenge you to a game of mahjong. Daily life asserts itself in the hutongs (ancient networks of alleys), to the delight of locals and tourists.

Losing yourself in this maze of alleys is the best way to understand what might be called 'the art of living' the Chinese way.

content.title: Beijing Opera: learn about the cultural pastimes of the ancestors

introduction.small: An entire sumptuous house dedicated to Chinese opera and traditional culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Beijing Opera: learn about the cultural pastimes of the ancestors

paragraphs.text:
Built during the reign of Qing Emperor Jiaqing in 1807, this place continues the famous tradition of Beijing opera. Not only have the greatest artists performed here, but key events in the political history of the country also happened here: the first meeting of the Kuomintang, the ruling party before the arrival of the communists, was held here. The opera house now aims to educate people about its cultural heritage.

This museum offers a history of traditional opera, which is made up of a rich mix of sounds, images, and cultural references; you will also find a gallery of the greatest opera performers in costume. This form of folk art is highly appreciated by the Chinese, who are great music lovers and enthusiastic connoisseurs.

Then, after the visit, why not enjoy the show offered in the large hall? Enjoy this cultural plunge into the past.

Beijing Opera (Huguang Guild Hall)
3 Hufang Road
Xicheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)13 5525 27373

www.huguangguildhall.com

content.title: The Orchid: wellness and relaxation

introduction.small: Travel differently as a host rather than a guest.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Orchid: wellness and relaxation

paragraphs.text:
The Orchid was born of an encounter between a young Tibetan and a Canadian. Beginning as tourists in the city, they both created strong ties with Beijing, and wanted to cement this with a common project: to open a hotel that would feel like you were staying with family or friends. The duo found a place in the heart of old Beijing, next to the Bell and Drum Towers. Completely renovated and landscaped, it now receives guests from all over the world.

The hotel offers five categories of charming rooms, some with a small private garden, perfect for a relaxing stay after a day of intense sightseeing. Others offer breath-taking views of the surrounding rooftops. Here, you will perceive the city in another way; welcomed in this friendly environment, you are in contact with another Beijing, one that is luxurious yet full of human warmth.

The Orchid
65 Baochao Hutong
Dongcheng District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 8565 9295

www.theorchidbeijing.com

Rooms: from 1,150 CNY

content.title: Hotel Éclat: a glass-encased jewel

introduction.small: A gustatory stopping place between art, nature, luxury, and ecology.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Éclat: a glass-encased jewel

paragraphs.text:
The view from the sublime and ultra-contemporary Hotel Éclat is an exceptional experience. Alongside offices and luxury stores in a glass pyramid, the hotel gives you the feeling of entering an imaginary world. There are Dalí Surrealist bronzes alongside works by Andy Warhol and current Chinese artists.

On each floor and behind each door, a unique world opens up to you, sometimes in the style of an English gentleman's club with thick carpets and Chesterfield sofas, and sometimes Japanese-inspired. Some 20 suites have a Jacuzzi, terrace, and jet pool. This construction is environmentally responsible: rainwater is filtered, like the air; ultra-insulating glass walls protect travellers from polar winter cold. In the lobby, a tropical forest offers a moment of calm for the eyes as well as for the mind.

This is a five-star hotel that deserves its reputation.

Hôtel Éclat
9 Dongdaqiao Road
Chaoyang District
Beijing

+86 (0)10 8561 2888

www.eclathotels.com/beijing/

Rooms: from 1,679 CNY

content.title: Acrobatics at the Chaoyang Theater

introduction.small: The colourful, irresistible Chinese circus will transport you back to your childhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Acrobatics at the Chaoyang Theater

paragraphs.text:
A popular form of entertainment since imperial times, the circus reflects both the plurimillenial traditions of the court and the Chinese passion for physical prowess. Talented gymnasts, contortionists, high-wire walkers, and acrobats perpetuate this art and defy the laws of gravity as well as those of reason.

Chaoyang Theatre is highly regarded throughout China and beyond its borders. Shows are punctuated by the ooohs and ahhhhs of enthusiastic spectators. The Chinese are great connoisseurs of this art, and they appreciate talent and the technical difficulty of an acrobatic performance. Transported to a high-flying China, you will find your child's soul.

Chaoyang Theater
36 Dongsanhuan North Road
Chaoyang District
Beijing

+86 (1)35 5252 7373

www.chaoyangtheatre.com

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Beijing
content.introduction: Beijing has a temperate and continental monsoon climate, with four distinct seasons. Winters are cold and dry. Summers are hot and humid, with temperatures easily reaching 40°C (104°F) or higher during particularly punishing heat waves. Beijing can also be pummelled by heavy, warm rains at times in the summer.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in China is the Yuan (CNY).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Beijing Capital International Airport
airports.description:
The Beijing Capital International Airport is located about 25 kilometres (16 miles) north of the city centre.
  • Three terminals:
    • Terminal 1
    • Terminal 2 (Air France)
    • Terminal 3

Getting from the airport to Beijing and back:
  • By car
    • The Airport Expressway, the Northern Airport Line and the Southern Airport Line are the main motorways connecting the airport and the city.
    • Parking at Terminal 3 is free for the first 30 minutes, then CNY 2.5 for 30 minutes. The charge for 24 hours is CNY 80.
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals hall at Terminal 2.
  • By train
    • The Airport Express links central Beijing to Terminals 2 and 3 within about 20 minutes. Trains run at 10-minute intervals every day between 6:00 a.m. and 10:30 p.m. The fare is CNY 25 per person.
  • By bus
    • 9 bus lines connect the airport to various points in central Beijing (lines 3, 4 and 5 only run in both ways to and from the airport). Buses run about every 30 minutes and most trips take about 90 minutes. Fares are about CNY 4 to 6 per person.
  • By taxi
    • Official taxis (in various bicolour configurations, but always with a yellow stripe across the middle) are available at each terminal, outside the upper level. Travel time to central Beijing is about 25 minutes and fares range from CNY 100 to CNY 180.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi), valet parking available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +86 (0)10 96158
  • Website: en.bcia.com.cn

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Beijing
transportation.description: Getting around Beijing is relatively simple. The Beijing Subway, which underwent major renovation in preparation for the 2008 Olympic Games, is quick and convenient. Taxis are another option, and fares are relatively inexpensive. Lastly, if it appeals to you, renting a bicycle is the best solution for really exploring the city.

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. Beijing counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists. If you are under medical treatment, it is recommended to carry sufficient prescribed medicine. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic Chinese phrases that will make your stay in Beijing a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: Nǐ hǎo
Could you repeat ?: Máfan nín zài chóngfù yībiàn
What time is it ?: Qǐngwèn xiànzài jǐ diǎn ?
Do you have (…)?: Qǐngwèn nín yǒu ma (…) ?
Where can I find (…)?: Qǐngwèn nǎlǐ kěyǐ zhǎodào (…) ?
Where can I buy (…)?: Qǐngwèn nǎlǐ kěyǐ mǎi dào (...) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Beijing
localCalendar.description:
There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Beijing each year.
The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January or February: Chinese New Year (national holiday)
events.description: As China is still largely a rural country, Chinese New Year celebrations are exceedingly important, emphasizing rebirth and renewal. Coinciding with the new moon on the first day of the first lunar month, in ancient times the start of the festival marked the beginning of the new season for planting crops, the ideal moment to pray for a good harvest. For three days, celebrations involve merrymaking and entertainment of many kinds, both at home with family members and outside in the streets: firecrackers to ward off evil spirits and demons, fireworks, etc.

events.title: February or March: Lantern Festival (Yuanxiao Jie, celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Colourful paper lanterns line the streets of Beijing and throughout China on this day. Children and adults parade through the city carrying long bamboo poles hung with smaller lanterns. This festival officially ends Chinese New Year celebrations.

events.title: August – Seventh day of the seventh lunar month : Double Seventh Festival (Qixi, celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also known as the Chinese Valentine's Day, this romantic festival has been celebrated in China for centuries. Traditionally, this was the day when young, single women prayed to attract a husband. The name of the festival refers to the seventh daughter of the Jade Emperor, a weaving maid, who was only allowed by her father to see her beloved, a lowly cowherd, once a year, on the seventh day of the seventh lunar month. Gifts of bouquets of flowers or chocolates, special dates, romantic dinners, and dance parties are among the celebrations during this day, highly anticipated by all single people in Beijing.

events.title: September or October – Fifteenth day of the eighth lunar month: Mid-Autumn Festival (Zhongqiu Jie, celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also known as the Moon Festival, this is the day in the year when the moon is particularly round and bright, a symbol of unity and familial happiness. The main feature of this traditional festival is the sharing of cakes with family and friends.

events.title: October 1: National Day (Guoqing Jie, national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, proclaimed by Mao Zedong. Festivities held throughout the city include fireworks, military parades, concerts and dance parties.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Beijing
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you must obtain a visa to enter and stay in China (different formalities apply for Hong Kong). Your passport must be valid for at least six months beyond the period of your stay.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Beijing and China, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations.

Comprehensive information that may be helpful is also provided on the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ website:

https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays-destination/chine/

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 5 p.m., Saturday from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m.

banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m., Saturday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., and Sunday from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m.

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime: No daylight savings time in China.
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
Tipping is not expected in Beijing's restaurants and cafés. On the other hand, it is quite common to thank tour guides and drivers by offering a small gratuity. Of course, the amount you choose to give is entirely up to you.
